document.docAuthor: Frey, Maximilian & Klaiber, Iris & Conrad, Jürgen & Spring, Otmar
document.docTitle: CYP71BL9, the missing link in costunolide synthesis of sunflower

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: CYP71BL9, the missing link in costunolide synthesis of sunflower

paragraph.docTitle: CYP71BL9, the missing link in costunolide synthesis of sunflower

subSection.paragraph:
Maximilian Frey a, ∗ , Iris Klaiber b , Jürgen Conrad c , Otmar Spring a a
Institute of Biology, Biochemistry of Plant Secondary Metabolism (190b), University of Hohenheim, Garbenstrasse 30, 70593, Stuttgart, Germany

paragraph.emphasis: Mass Spectrometry Unit, Core Facility Hohenheim, University of Hohenheim, Emil-Wolff-Str. 12, 70599, Stuttgart, Germany
Institute of Chemistry, University of Hohenheim, Garbenstrasse 30, 70593, Stuttgart, Germany

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

Helianthus annuus
L.
Sunflower
Enzyme characterization
Sesquiterpene lactone
Costunolide synthase
p450 enzyme
CYP71BL9
Hydroxylation
CYP71BL subfamily
Enzyme phylogeny
A B S T R A C T

Despite intensive research in recent years, the biosynthetic route to costunolide in sunflower so far remained obscured. Additional P450 sequences from public sunflower transcriptomic database were screened to search for candidate enzymes which are able to introduce the 6α-hydroxy-group required for the esterification with the carboxy group of germacarane A acid, the final step in costunolide formation. CYP71BL9, a new P450 enzyme from sunflower was shown to catalyze this hydroxylation, hence being identified as HaCOS. Phylogentically, HaCOS is closer related to HaG8H than to any other known costunolide synthase in Asteraceae .The enzyme was successfully employed to reconstruct the sunflower biosynthesis of costunolide in transformed tobacco. Contrary, in yeast, only minor amounts of sesquiterpene lactone was produced, while 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid was formed instead. HaCOS in combination with HaG8H produced 8β-hydroxycostunolide (eupatolide) in transformed plants, thus indicating that sunflower possesses two independent modes of eupatolide synthesis via HaCOS and via HaES. The lack of HaCOS expression and of costunolide in trichomes suggests that the enzyme triggers the costunolied synthesis of the inner tissues of sunflower and might be linked to growth regulation processes.

The biosynthetic route to costunolide is well established for most Astereaceae lineages. All Asteraceae possess the genes to produce the precursor, germacrene A acid, from farnesyl-diphospahte (FPP) ( Nguyen et al., 2010 , 2016 ): Germacrene A synthase (GAS) converts FPP to germacrene A and germacrene A oxidase (GAO) catalyzes the subsequent three-step oxidation to germacrene A acid (GAA) ( Göpfert et al., 2009 ; Nguyen et al., 2010 , 2016 ). Ikezawa et al. (2011) expressed the first costunolide synthase (LsCOS) from
Lactuca sativa
in combination with sunflower HaGAS and HaGAO in yeast cells. It was shown that the enzyme introduces a 6α-hydroxy-group which spontaneusly cyclizes germacrene A acid to costunoilde. EST sequence comparison showed that most Asteraceae lineages possess LsCOS homologs and some of these have subsequently been characterized ( Eljounaidi et al., 2014 ; Liu et al., 2011 ; Ramirez et al., 2013 ). However, in sunflower and related species of the Heliantheae tribe, LsCOS homologs were absent, whereas ESTs homolgous to HaG8H could be found ( Ikezawa et al., 2011 ). Most recently, it was shown that the STL present in sunflower capitate glandular trichomes are formed via 6α-hydroxylation of 8sshydroxy-germacrene A acid by means of the socalled eupatolide synthase HaES ( Frey et al., 2018 ). The formation of costunolide (without 8β-hydroxy group) and dehydrocostuslactone in inner tissues of sunflower remained elusive, although, a costunolide 14-hydroxylase was recently found in sunflower ( Frey et al., 2019 ). Therefore, we screened additional P450 sequences from public sunflower transcriptomic database to search for candidate enzymes for the final step in costunolide synthesis. CYP71BL9, a homolog to HaG8H was identified and showed the capacity to hydroxylate germacrene A acid in 6α position, the prerequisite for the subsequent lactonization to costunolide. This
Helianthus annuus
costunolide synthase (HaCOS, CYP71BL9) is characterized here. We also show, how two alternative pathways can lead to the same end product eupatolide and that the reconstruction in a yeast system can lead to unusual previously undescribed products.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Phylogeny of cytochrome p450 enzymes. Phylogeny of cytochrome p450 enzymes found in the Asteraceae plant family involved in sesquiterpene lactone biosynthesis. All enzymes shown are members of the CYP71 family. The classification in the subfamilies CYP71AV and CYP71BL is shown on the right side. The numbers at the nodes show bootstrap values from 1000 iterations.

subSection.paragraph:
Previously, from the cDNA of
Helianthus annuus
cv. HA300 several candidate genes were described that had a similar expression pattern in a public transcriptome database (Heliagene). This led to the characterization of the
Helianthus annuus
eupatolide synthase ( Frey et al., 2018 ). We found in this database one accession that had a similar expression pattern to HaGAO. This gene was predominantly expressed in leaves and bracts and had a high sequence similarity to both HaG8H (the only so far characterized CYP71BL enzyme from sunflower) and to the costunolide synthases from
Tanacetum
and other Asteraceae species. Using 5′and 3′RACE PCR we identified the whole open reading frame and the UTR regions of this gene, that was officially assigned CYP71BL9 (http://drnelson.uthsc.edu/cytochromeP450.html). The CYP71BL subfamily comprises only genes that use germacrene A acid as a substrate. In this group, CYP71BL9 clustered together with the
H. annuus
germacrene A acid 8β-hydroxylase HaG8H (CYP71BL1), but clearly separated from yet characterized costunolide synthases ( Fig. 1 ).

emphasis.heading: 2.2. Reconstruction of the costunolide biosynthesis in Nicotiana
benthamiana

subSection.paragraph:
The biosynthetic pathway of germacrene A acid was recently resonstructed in
Nicotiana benthamiana
using the native sunflower enzymes HaGAS1 and HaGAO ( Frey et al., 2018 , 2019 ). Ten enzyme candidates from
H. annuus
were now tested downstream of germacrene A acid and the
Lactuca sativa
costunolide synthase LsCOS (CYP71BL2) was used as a positive control. The expression of the candidate gene CYP71BL9 [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + CYP71BL9] led to two major peaks (peak a , 9.00 min) and (peak b , 9.15 min), that were absent in the negative control [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO] ( Fig. 2A ). The masses and UV spectra of peak a and b indicated that these peaks could be the SH adducts costunolide-cysteine and costunolide-glutathione Fig..2B–D ). Indeed, comparison of retention time, exact mass and mass spectrum with synthetic adducts identified these peaks as costunolide-cysteine and costunolide-glutathione (peak a and b in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2 ). Free costunolide ( c **,14.18 min in Fig. 2A ) was only detected in trace amounts. In general, the production of costunolide (and its SH adducts) by CYP71BL9 was higher than in the control experiment with LsCOS. While both LsCOS and CYP71BL9 converted GAA to costunolide in planta , the composition of the costunolide derivatives was different, with LsCOS producing relatively less contunolide-glutathione ( Fig. S3 ). The costunolide-glutathione peak produced by LsCOS could only be deduced from the extracted ion chromatogram (peak b *). The generation of glutathione and cysteine conjugates with α-methylene-γ-lactones as well as other unspecific reactions in
Nicotiana benthamiana
has been widely reported and the underlying mechanisms are well understood ( Frey, 2020 ).

emphasis.heading: 2.3. Two alternative routes to eupatolide biosynthesis in Nicotiana
benthamiana

subSection.paragraph:
After CYP71BL9 was shown to convert germacrene A acid into costunolide we investigated if the co-expression of CYP71BL9 with the germacrene A acid 8β-hydroxylase (CYP71BL1) would lead to new enzyme products. Indeed, the introduction of CYP71BL9 [p19/ DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + HaG8H + CYP71BL9] led to the formation of eupatolide which was found as cystein- and glutathion-adduct in HPLC diagrams (peak d and h in Fig. 3A–E ). The negative control [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + HaG8H] did not show these products. The identity of eupatolide-adducts was confirmed by comparison to synthetic adducts ( Fig. S4 and Fig. S5). As a main intermediate product, costunolide-cysteine was detected ( Fig. 3A , peak a ). This was in contrast to the previously described co-expression of HaG8H with
H. annuus
eupatolide synthase HaES ( Frey et al., 2018 ) which also led to the production of eupatolide, but without forming costunolide adducts. Instead, the inunolide SH adducts inunolide-cystein and inunolide-GSH ( Fig. 3A , peak l and m ) were found and four peak tandems that were tentatively assigned to eudesmanolide rearrangement products of eupatolide-SH adducts ( Frey et al., 2018 ). Apparently, the combination of HaG8H and HaES, as well as HaG8H and CYP71BL9 downstream of GAA lead to the production of eupatolide, but on different biosynthetic routes. When HaG8H and HaES were expressed together, GAA was converted to 8β-OH-GAA. 8β-OHGAA then partly cyclized to inunolide and partly was converted by HaES to eupatolide. No costunolide or its SH adducts were detected in plants expressing this set of enzymes indicating that the metabolic route did not pass via costunolide (Table 1). When HaES was replaced with CYP71BL9, there was mainly costunolide, only very little inunolide, and 8β-hydroxy-cyclocostunolide derivatives. This indicates, that with CYP71BL9, in the first step, costunolide was produced which subsequently was converted to eupatolide by the 8β-hydroxylation of HaG8H. In yeast and plant expression systems, it has already been reported that acid-induced rearrangement can be observed for GAA, 8βhydroxy-GAA and inunolide, but not for the 6,7-cis lactone costunolide ( Frey et al., 2018 ; Ikezawa et al., 2011 ; Liu et al., 2011 ; Nguyen et al., 2010 ). So far, for the biosynthesis of STL in Asteraceae only linear pathways have been elucidated ( Ikezawa et al., 2011 ; Liu et al., 2014 ; Ro et al., 2006 ), while the different pattern of rearrangement products here, clearly indicated two possible independent pathways leading to the same core STL skeleton.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. Comparison of the expression of LsCOS and CYP71BL9 in planta. Comparison of extracts from
N. benthamiana
leaves transiently transformed with the vectors [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO], [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO+ LsCOS] und [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + CYP71BL9]; A, LC-MS chromatograms; B, UV and (+) MS spectrum von peak a; C, Conversion of germacrene A acid to costunolide by LsCOS and CYP71BL9 as well as addition reaction to costunolide-glutathione (peak b); D, UV and (+) MS spectrum of peak b; peak a: costunolide-cysteine, Peak b: costunolide-glutathione, (*) costunolide-glutathione shown in EIC, (**) Traces of free costunolide shown (peak c); BPC: base peak count, EIC: extracted ion chromatogram

Fig. 3. Two alternative pathways of eupatolide biosynthesis. Comparison of the extracts of transiently transformed
N. benthamiana
leaves carrying the vector combinations [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + HaG8H], [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + HaG8H + HaES] and [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + HaG8H + CYP71BL9]; A, LC-MS chromatograms; B, UV and (+) MS spectrum of peak d; C, UV and (+) MS spectrum of peak h; D, EIC (C 18 H 27 NO 5 S) [M +H] + = 370; E, EIC (C H N O S) [M+H] + = 556; F, scheme, conversion of germacrene A acid to eupatolide by HaG8H and HaES; G, scheme, conversion of 25 37 3 9 germacrene A acid to eupatolide by HaG8H and CYP71BL9

subSection.paragraph: When CYP71BL9 was expressed together with the substrate vector for GAA [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR| Ura:CYP71BL9], a new product (peak a, 10.19 min, λ max = 204 nm ) appeared in HPLC analysis in comparison to the negative control [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR| Ura:empty] (data not shown). When CYP71BL9 was expressed downstream of 8β-OH-GAA [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR/HaG8H|Ura:CYP71BL9], peak a was still detected together with a second peak (peak b , 15.5 min, λ max = 207 nm ) ( Fig. 4A ). A small amount of peak b could be collected from the HPLC runs. It showed the same retention time and absorption spectrum as the costunolide standard ( Fig. 4B ). The identity of the purified peak b with costunolide was confirmed by MS-MS spectra ( Fig 4 ,D-E) and 1H NMR analysis. Peak a was purified by preparative HPLC . NMR analysis and comparison of NMR data to a structurally similar farnesyl lactone ( Hubert et al., 2015 ) identified the compound as 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid. The formation of this side product may be caused by a reaction of farnesol with CYP71BL9. The underlying reaction mechanism remains unclear, however.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.5. Structural comparison of CYP71BL9 and CYP71BL1

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. The expression of candidate gene CYP71BL9 in combination with HaG8H in yeast. A, HPLC comparison of extracts from yeast strains [EPY300:Leu2d:GAS/ CR/GAO/HaG8H||Ura:CYP71Bl9] and control [EPY300:Leu2d:GAS/CR/GAO/HaG8H||Ura:empty] peak a: CYP71BL9 enzyme product, peak b: enzyme product of HaG8H and CYP71BL9 at 15.61 min; B, DAD-chromatogram, peak b purified, in comparison with costunolide standard; C UV–Vis spectrum of peak b and costunolide; D, (+) MS 2 spectrum of peak b; E, (+) MS 2 spectrum of costunolide; F, reaction scheme for the generation of costunolide with HaG8H and CYP71BL9 (not shown: 8βhydroxy-germacrene A acid, 11.50 min)

subSection.paragraph:
In our study we have characterized the
Helianthus annuus
costunolide synthase HaCOS (CYP71BL9) that converted germacrene A acid to costunolide, the commonly presumed precursor of a wide range of STL. Our results will fuel the elucidation of biosynthetic routes downstream of costunolide in sunflower and related species of the Heliantheae tribe and the understanding of the physiological role of costunolide and DCL in sunflower.

heading.emphasis: 4.1. Identification of candidate genes, cloning and phylogeny

subSection.paragraph: Candidate gene fragments were retrieved from a public sunflower transcriptomic database (www.heliagene.org) and filtered by similarity to known P450 enzymes involved in Asteraceae STL metabolism regarding amino acid identity and gene expression pattern as previously described ( Frey et al., 2018 ). The whole open reading frame and UTS regions of CYP71BL9 was identified by 3′and 5′RACE (Clontech Laboratories, Inc., Mountain View, CA, USA ).

The cds of CYP71BL9 was amplified from bract cDNA using a proofreading polymerase, and cloned into the MCS1 site of the pESC-Ura plasmid using the primers
GTC AAT GAA TTC ATG GAG CCT TTC ACA ATT TTC TTC
and
GTC AAT ACT AGT CTA ATT TGG TTC TGA TAC GGA GAT AGG
. Amino acid sequences for phylogeny were aligned with BioEdit and a phylogeny was constructed with MEGA6 (1000 Bootstraps). CYP71BL9 and genes upstream in the biosynthetic pathway were inserted into the vector pLIFE33 by USER cloning as previously described ( Bitinaite et al., 2007 ; Frey et al., 2018 ; Nour-Eldin et al., 2006 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Pathway reconstruction in yeast and Nicotiana benthamiana

emphasis.heading: 4.3. Characterization of enzyme products by HPLC NMR spectroscopy and
mass spectrometry

subSection.paragraph:
Extracts from yeast cultures were analyzed by HPLC-DAD (Prominence system Shimadzu Germany GmbH, Duisburg) with a Kromasil C18 column (100 18C, 25 cm × 4 mm x 5 μm particle size; MZ Analysentechnik, Mainz, Germany ). After the injection of 80 μl (corresponding to 2 mL culture volume), extracts were separated using the following program: min 40–100 B, 1 min 100 B, 4 min 40 B; A:ddH 2 O/ 0.01% TFA B: ACN, 1 ml/min). 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid and costunolide were purified from yeast cultures by HPLC and anylzed by NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. NMR spectrometry was conducted with a 500 MHz Varian Unity Inova (Varian, Inc./Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA, USA ) spectrometer with a 3 mm ID PFG probe in 3 mm NMR vials. Spectra were referenced to the solvent signal of chloroform (δH/C 7.27/77 ppm). For a full structural analysis, 1H NMR, 1D TOCSY and several 2D spectra were recorded (gCOSY, gHSQAD, gHMBCAD, ROESY, NOESY, TOCSY). For mass spectrometry the purified compound was re-run on a LC-MS system with Agilent (Waldbronn, Germany ) 1290 UHPLC on a HSS T3 column (1.8 μm particle size, 50 mm × 2.1 mm , Waters, Dublin , Ireland ) in combination with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QTRAP 5500, LC-MS/MS system (AB Sciex Instruments, Darmstadt, Germany ) Q3-MS, ESI-pos. Screening of extracts from
Nicotiana benthamiana
with putative enzyme products, and comparison of enzyme products to synthetic adducts was conducted using LC-MS as previously described ( Frey et al., 2018 ).
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112430.
